thoughts.summary: Explaining Codex app multi-agent workflows
thoughts.content: The Codex app supports multi-agent workflows with separate threads for tasks, a project-based sidebar, and parallel processing across projects. It features built-in Git management, skill systems, automations, and modes like Local/Cloud. Each agent has its own cloud thread environment, and the app excels at orchestration with context switching and environment management.

thoughts.summary: Explaining multi-agent orchestration and setup
thoughts.content: In multi-agent orchestration, you manage several agent threads, each in its own isolated worktree or cloud environment. These threads run in parallel, with quick context switching via a project sidebar. Using skills and automations, agents share instructions/scripts for consistency. The system integrates with an IDE, allowing quick review, comments, and coordination with other tools.

parts:
The new Codex app is basically built as a **human “agent manager”**: you spin up multiple agent threads, keep their code changes isolated, and supervise/merge outcomes without constantly juggling terminals, branches, or editor state. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search2

## What “multi-agent” looks like in the app

### 1) Parallel agent threads (one thread ≈ one agent task)
- You can run **multiple Codex threads at once**, organized by **projects**, and switch between them without losing context. citeturn0search0turn0search1  
- This is the core multi-agent workflow: *delegate distinct tasks to distinct threads* (e.g., “refactor module”, “write tests”, “update docs”) and let them progress in parallel. citeturn0search0turn0search2

### 2) Isolation via built-in Git worktrees (so agents don’t collide)
- The app has **built-in Git worktree support**, so each thread/agent can work in an **isolated checkout** of the same repo. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search5  
- Practically: you can explore competing approaches (or run multiple fixes) without corrupting your main working tree or constantly stashing/rebasing. citeturn0search0turn0search1

### 3) Review + steering loop is first-class (diffs, inline comments, staging)
- Each thread surfaces changes as a **reviewable diff**; you can **comment on the diff**, and the agent can incorporate that feedback. citeturn0search0turn0search5  
- Built-in Git actions include **stage/revert chunks**, commit, push, and even create pull requests (depending on mode/config). citeturn0search5turn0search1  
This matters for multi-agent work because you can run many threads and still keep quality control tight.

### 4) Multiple execution modes per thread (Local / Worktree / Cloud)
- Each thread runs in a selected **mode**:
  - **Local** (works directly in your project directory),
  - **Worktree** (isolated changes),
  - **Cloud** (remote execution in a configured environment). citeturn0search5turn0search9  
This lets you choose: keep small tasks local, isolate risky tasks in worktrees, and offload heavy/long tasks to cloud. citeturn0search5turn0search9

### 5) “Skills” make agents reusable and consistent
- The app supports **agent skills**: packaged instructions/resources/scripts that Codex can invoke to follow a workflow reliably. citeturn0search0turn0search11turn0search5  
- Skills are shareable across the app, CLI, and IDE extension—useful when you have multiple agents and want them to behave consistently (same conventions, same checks, same tooling). citeturn0search1turn0search11

### 6) Automations let “agents” run recurring jobs in the background
- The app supports **automations** (often paired with skills) for routine tasks like checks, reporting, or other scheduled workflows. citeturn0search1turn0search5  
This is a different flavor of multi-agent: you can have “always-on” background threads doing maintenance while you run interactive threads for feature work.

### 7) It’s designed to sit on top of your existing Codex workflows (CLI/IDE sync)
- The app picks up history/config from Codex CLI and can sync with the IDE extension in the same project, including “auto context” based on files you’re viewing. citeturn0search0turn0search5  
That reduces friction when you’re coordinating multiple threads: you can bounce between app ↔ editor without losing the plot.

## What it does *not* automatically do (important nuance)
- It’s not “multi-agent orchestration” in the sense of agents autonomously messaging/negotiating with each other. The app is more like an **air-traffic control tower** where *you* coordinate parallel threads. citeturn0search0turn0search1  
- If you want **programmatic** multi-agent pipelines (specialized agents with deterministic handoffs), entity["organization","OpenAI","ai research company"] points you to orchestrating Codex (typically via the CLI exposed as a **Model Context Protocol (MCP)** server) using the Agents SDK. citeturn0search4turn0search3  

## A concrete way to use it as a multi-agent “team”
Example setup for a repo:
1. **Thread A (Worktree):** “Fix failing tests + minimal code changes.”
2. **Thread B (Worktree):** “Refactor module X for readability; no behavior change.”
3. **Thread C (Cloud):** “Run full test suite + lint + generate a failure report.”
4. Review diffs for A/B, leave inline comments, stage only the chunks you accept, then merge/PR.

That pattern—**parallel threads + isolated worktrees + diff-based supervision + reusable skills**—is the app’s main multi-agent story. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search5

parts:
## What “agent skills” are in Codex
A **skill** is a small, reusable capability you can teach Codex: it bundles **(a)** metadata that helps Codex decide *when* to use it and **(b)** instructions/resources/scripts that define *how* to do the task.

Codex loads skills with **progressive disclosure**: on startup it reads only each skill’s **`name` + `description`**, and only injects the full `SKILL.md` (and any referenced assets) when the skill is actually invoked. citeturn3view1turn3view2

Codex can use a skill in two ways:
- **Explicit invocation**: you pick a skill (via `/skills` or by typing `$…`) citeturn3view1turn5view0  
- **Implicit invocation**: Codex auto-selects a skill when your prompt matches the skill’s description citeturn3view1turn3view2

---

## Where skills live (repo vs user vs admin)
Codex scans multiple “skill roots,” so you can scope skills to **a repo** (shared with collaborators) or **your machine** (personal defaults). Supported locations include: citeturn3view1

- **Repo-scoped**:  
  - `$CWD/.codex/skills`  
  - `$CWD/../.codex/skills`  
  - `$REPO_ROOT/.codex/skills`
- **User-scoped**: `$CODEX_HOME/skills` (macOS/Linux default: `~/.codex/skills`)
- **Admin/system**: `/etc/codex/skills` plus built-in system skills

---

## The minimum skill format (what files to create)
A skill is **a folder** containing a **`SKILL.md`** with YAML front matter. Required fields:  
- `name`: non-empty, ≤100 chars, single line  
- `description`: non-empty, ≤500 chars, single line  
The rest of the file is Markdown instructions. citeturn3view2

Example `SKILL.md` skeleton:

```md
---
name: draft-commit-message
description: Draft a Conventional Commits message when the user asks for help writing a commit message.
---

## What to do
- Ask for the change summary if missing
- Output `type(scope): summary` (<= 72 chars)
- Add `BREAKING CHANGE:` footer if needed
```

Codex also supports a standard skill directory layout where you keep scripts/templates/docs on disk (so they don’t bloat context): citeturn3view2

```text
my-skill/
  SKILL.md
  scripts/        # optional
  references/     # optional
  assets/         # optional
  agents/
    openai.yaml   # optional (UI + dependencies)
```

---

## Creating a skill the “Codex-native” way (recommended)
Codex ships with a built-in skill that scaffolds new skills:

```text
$skill-creator
```

You can add extra instructions after invoking it, e.g.:

```text
$skill-creator

Create a skill that drafts a conventional commit message based on a short summary of changes.
```

The creator helps you decide:
- what the skill does,
- when it should trigger,
- whether it should be **instruction-only** (recommended default) or script-backed. citeturn3view2

---

## Creating a skill manually (fast + explicit)
Choose a scope, create a folder, add `SKILL.md`, then restart Codex. citeturn3view2

```bash
# User-scoped (macOS/Linux default)
mkdir -p ~/.codex/skills/my-skill

# Repo-scoped (commit to your repo)
mkdir -p .codex/skills/my-skill
```

Then create:

```bash
$EDITOR .codex/skills/my-skill/SKILL.md
```

---

## Enabling / disabling skills (and why yours “doesn’t show up”)
You can disable a specific skill (experimental) via `~/.codex/config.toml` using `[[skills.config]]` and a path, then restart Codex. citeturn3view1turn1view2

```toml
[[skills.config]]
path = "/path/to/skill"
enabled = false
```

If a skill doesn’t appear, the docs call out the usual causes: wrong filename (`SKILL.md`), wrong location, not restarting, malformed YAML, or name/description length issues. citeturn3view2turn1view1

Codex configuration is layered: user defaults live in `~/.codex/config.toml`, with optional project overrides in `.codex/config.toml` (only loaded for trusted projects). citeturn6view0

---

## How to invoke skills in practice (App vs CLI vs IDE)

### Codex app (macOS)
- Type **`$`** in the thread composer to explicitly invoke a skill. citeturn5view0  
- Enabled skills can also show up as **slash commands** (e.g. `/imagegen`). citeturn5view0

### Codex CLI / IDE extension
- Skills can be explicitly selected via **`/skills`** or by referencing them with **`$skill-name`**. citeturn3view1turn1view4

A reliable pattern while you’re developing a skill is to start with explicit invocation (so you can see exactly how it behaves), then later rely on implicit triggering once your `description` is tight. citeturn1view4turn3view2

---

## Installing skills from a catalog
Codex also ships a `$skill-installer` flow for pulling skills (including experimental ones) from a curated GitHub catalog. Example from the docs: citeturn3view1

```text
$skill-installer install the create-plan skill from the .experimental folder
```

(After installing, restart Codex to load the new skill.) citeturn3view1

---

## Advanced: make a skill “app-friendly” + declare tool dependencies
If you add `agents/openai.yaml`, you can:
1) customize how the skill appears in the Codex app (name/icon/color), and  
2) declare **Model Context Protocol (MCP)** dependencies the skill needs.

Example (as documented): citeturn3view2turn0search6

```yaml
interface:
  display_name: "Docs helper"
  short_description: "Search OpenAI dev docs and cite results"
  icon_small: "./assets/small-logo.svg"
  icon_large: "./assets/large-logo.png"
  brand_color: "#3B82F6"
  default_prompt: "Use this skill to answer API questions with citations."

dependencies:
  tools:
    - type: "mcp"
      value: "openaiDeveloperDocs"
      description: "OpenAI Docs MCP server"
      transport: "streamable_http"
      url: "https://developers.openai.com/mcp"
```

If a dependency requires OAuth, Codex will kick off the auth flow automatically when the skill is used. citeturn3view2turn0search10

---

## Making skills *reliable* (how people usually mess this up)
The `description` is not “marketing copy.” It’s **agent-facing trigger logic**. If it’s vague, you’ll get:
- false negatives (skill won’t trigger),
- false positives (skill triggers when you didn’t want it). citeturn3view2turn1view4

A practical hardening loop from OpenAI’s evals guidance:
1) Define what “success” means (outcome/process/style/efficiency). citeturn1view4  
2) Manually trigger the skill via `/skills` or `$…` to expose hidden assumptions. citeturn1view4  
3) Add a small prompt set (10–20 cases) including “should not trigger” negatives. citeturn1view4  
4) For automation/CI runs, prefer `codex exec`; if the task needs to write files, use `--full-auto` (least privilege still applies). citeturn1view4

Example run pattern from the same guidance:

```bash
codex exec --full-auto \
  'Use the $setup-demo-app skill to create the project in this directory.'
```

---

If you tell me what kind of skills you want (e.g., “repo-specific lint+test gate,” “PR template generator,” “math worksheet pipeline”), I’ll draft a `SKILL.md` + an `agents/openai.yaml` that’s tight on triggers and safe on permissions.

parts:
Here’s a **fully worked “math tutoring worksheet factory” skill** you can drop into Codex. It’s designed for a one-teacher tutoring workflow: you specify level/topics/difficulty mix, and the agent reliably produces a LaTeX worksheet with **questions first**, then a **two-column concise answer key**.

This example uses (1) a **repo-scoped skill**, (2) an optional **script-backed generator** (Python + SymPy), and (3) an optional `agents/openai.yaml` so it shows nicely in the Codex app and can declare Model Context Protocol (MCP) dependencies if you have them. Skills are folder-based with a required `SKILL.md`; Codex only injects the skill name/description until you invoke it. citeturn1search0turn4view0turn5view0

---

## 1) Folder layout to add to your repo

Create this under your repo root:

```text
.codex/
  skills/
    sgmath-worksheet/
      SKILL.md
      agents/
        openai.yaml
      scripts/
        gen_worksheet.py
      assets/
        worksheet_template.tex
      references/
        house_style.md
```

Why this structure: Codex skills are a folder with `SKILL.md` plus optional scripts/resources; `agents/openai.yaml` is optional for appearance + MCP dependencies. citeturn1search0turn5view0turn4view0

---

## 2) `SKILL.md` (the heart of the skill)

Copy/paste:

```md
---
name: sgmath-worksheet
description: Generate a math tutoring worksheet (LaTeX) with questions + concise solutions at the end (2-column, smaller font). Use when the user asks for weekly practice sheets, topic drills, mixed revision papers, or “make N questions with answers” for secondary/JC math.
---

## Goal
Produce a LaTeX worksheet that matches a tutoring-house style:
- Questions first (numbered).
- Solutions consolidated at the end on a fresh page in smaller font, two-column format.
- Concise answers and minimal working (unless the user requests full solutions).
- No cartoons/extraneous text.

## Required inputs (ask if missing)
1) Level: e.g. Sec 1/2/3, O-Level E-Math, A-Math, JC H2
2) Topics list
3) Number of questions (and whether subparts count as one question)
4) Difficulty mix (e.g. 40% easy, 40% medium, 20% hard)
5) Constraints (e.g. avoid absolute value symbols; avoid piecewise; integers only; etc.)
6) Output preference:
   - "Just output the LaTeX here" OR
   - "Write files into the repo"

## Default assumptions (use if user is vague)
- N = 12 questions
- Mix = 4 easy, 5 medium, 3 hard
- Concise solutions only
- Produce LaTeX
- Use a reproducible seed and record it in the LaTeX header comment.

## Procedure
1) Restate the spec you will follow (level, topics, counts, constraints, seed).
2) Choose generation mode:
   A) Instruction-only mode: write LaTeX directly in chat using the template in assets/worksheet_template.tex.
   B) Script-backed mode: if scripts/gen_worksheet.py exists, run it to generate LaTeX deterministically.
3) Quality checks (must do):
   - No duplicates / near-duplicates.
   - Covers all requested topics.
   - Difficulty mix matches spec.
   - All answers are present and correspond to each question.
4) Output:
   - If user asked “write files”, create:
     worksheets/<YYYY-MM-DD>_<short-topic-slug>/
       worksheet.tex
       spec.json
   - Otherwise, paste the final LaTeX.

## If running commands
- Prefer safe local commands (python, latexmk/pdflatex).
- If compilation tools aren’t installed, do NOT thrash. Just output LaTeX.

## Definition of done
- A compilable LaTeX file with:
  - Title, level, topic list, date, seed
  - Questions section
  - New page
  - Two-column concise solutions section in smaller font
```

Notes:
- The `description` is intentionally explicit because Codex uses it to decide when the skill should trigger. citeturn4view0turn5view0

---

## 3) `agents/openai.yaml` (optional, but nice in the app)

This makes the skill show up cleanly in the Codex app UI and lets you declare MCP tool dependencies if you have them. citeturn5view0turn4view0

```yaml
interface:
  display_name: "SGMath Worksheet Factory"
  short_description: "Generate LaTeX worksheets + 2-col concise solutions for tutoring"
  brand_color: "#2563EB"
  default_prompt: "Create a worksheet from the spec; ensure solutions are concise and consolidated."

# Optional: declare MCP tools if you have them.
# Example: a private MCP server that exposes your question bank or syllabus notes.
# dependencies:
#   tools:
#     - type: "mcp"
#       value: "sgmathQuestionBank"
#       description: "Private question-bank MCP server"
#       transport: "streamable_http"
#       url: "http://localhost:7337/mcp"
```

---

## 4) `assets/worksheet_template.tex` (LaTeX template)

Minimal, robust, and matches your “solutions at end, smaller font, two columns” pattern:

```tex
% === Worksheet generated by Codex skill: sgmath-worksheet ===
% Level: %%LEVEL%%
% Topics: %%TOPICS%%
% Date: %%DATE%%
% Seed: %%SEED%%

\documentclass[11pt]{article}
\usepackage[a4paper,margin=1in]{geometry}
\usepackage{amsmath,amssymb}
\usepackage{enumitem}
\usepackage{multicol}

\setlist[enumerate]{itemsep=0.6em}

\begin{document}

\begin{center}
    {\Large \textbf{%%TITLE%%}}\\
    \vspace{2mm}
    {\normalsize %%SUBTITLE%%}\\
\end{center}

\section*{Questions}
\begin{enumerate}
%%QUESTIONS%%
\end{enumerate}

\newpage
\section*{Solutions (concise)}
{\small
\begin{multicols}{2}
\begin{enumerate}
%%SOLUTIONS%%
\end{enumerate}
\end{multicols}
}

\end{document}
```

---

## 5) `scripts/gen_worksheet.py` (script-backed deterministic generator)

This is a *starter library* of question templates typical for tutoring (linear equations, expansion/factorisation, indices, quadratics). It produces a ready-to-compile `.tex`.

**Install deps** (once) in the project environment:
- `pip install sympy`

Then script:

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""
Generate a LaTeX math worksheet + concise solutions.

Usage:
  python scripts/gen_worksheet.py --level "Sec 3 A-Math" \
    --title "Algebra Drill" \
    --topics "linear equations,expansion,factorisation,indices,quadratics" \
    --n 12 --easy 4 --medium 5 --hard 3 \
    --seed 20260203 \
    --out worksheets/2026-02-03_algebra/worksheet.tex \
    --spec worksheets/2026-02-03_algebra/spec.json
"""

from __future__ import annotations

import argparse
import json
import os
import random
from dataclasses import dataclass
from datetime import date
from typing import Callable, Dict, List, Tuple

import sympy as sp


# ---------------------------
# Question template framework
# ---------------------------

Difficulty = str  # "easy" | "medium" | "hard"

@dataclass
class QTemplate:
    id: str
    topic: str
    difficulty: Difficulty
    make: Callable[[random.Random], Tuple[str, str]]  # returns (question_latex, solution_latex)


x = sp.Symbol("x", integer=True, real=True)


def _rand_nonzero(rng: random.Random, lo: int, hi: int) -> int:
    while True:
        v = rng.randint(lo, hi)
        if v != 0:
            return v


def q_linear_solve_int(rng: random.Random) -> Tuple[str, str]:
    # Solve ax + b = cx + d with integer solution
    a = _rand_nonzero(rng, -9, 9)
    c = _rand_nonzero(rng, -9, 9)
    while c == a:
        c = _rand_nonzero(rng, -9, 9)

    sol = rng.randint(-9, 9)
    b = rng.randint(-12, 12)
    d = (a - c) * sol + b

    q = rf"Solve: \({a}x + {b} = {c}x + {d}\)."
    # concise: give x = ...
    s = rf"\(x = {sol}\)."
    return q, s


def q_expand_simplify(rng: random.Random) -> Tuple[str, str]:
    # Simplify: p(ax+b) - q(cx+d)
    p = _rand_nonzero(rng, -6, 6)
    qcoef = _rand_nonzero(rng, -6, 6)
    a = _rand_nonzero(rng, -9, 9)
    c = _rand_nonzero(rng, -9, 9)
    b = rng.randint(-12, 12)
    d = rng.randint(-12, 12)

    expr = p * (a * x + b) - qcoef * (c * x + d)
    simp = sp.expand(expr)

    q = rf"Simplify: \({sp.latex(p)}({sp.latex(a)}x {sp.latex(b) if b < 0 else '+'+sp.latex(b)}) - {sp.latex(qcoef)}({sp.latex(c)}x {sp.latex(d) if d < 0 else '+'+sp.latex(d)})\)."
    s = rf"\({sp.latex(simp)}\)."
    return q, s


def q_indices_simplify(rng: random.Random) -> Tuple[str, str]:
    # Simplify: (a^m * a^n) / a^k
    a = rng.choice([2, 3, 5, 7])
    m = rng.randint(2, 7)
    n = rng.randint(2, 7)
    k = rng.randint(1, 6)
    expr = (a**m * a**n) / (a**k)
    simp = sp.simplify(expr)

    q = rf"Simplify: \(\dfrac{{{a}^{m}\cdot {a}^{n}}}{{{a}^{k}}}\)."
    s = rf"\({sp.latex(simp)}\)."
    return q, s


def q_factorise_monic_quadratic(rng: random.Random) -> Tuple[str, str]:
    # Factorise x^2 + px + q with integer roots
    r1 = rng.randint(-9, 9)
    r2 = rng.randint(-9, 9)
    while r1 == 0 or r2 == 0:
        r1 = rng.randint(-9, 9)
        r2 = rng.randint(-9, 9)

    p = -(r1 + r2)
    qconst = r1 * r2
    poly = x**2 + p*x + qconst
    fac = sp.factor(poly)

    # format signs nicely
    q = rf"Factorise fully: \({sp.latex(poly)}\)."
    s = rf"\({sp.latex(fac)}\)."
    return q, s


def q_quadratic_solve_factor(rng: random.Random) -> Tuple[str, str]:
    # Solve x^2 + px + q = 0 with integer roots
    r1 = rng.randint(-7, 7)
    r2 = rng.randint(-7, 7)
    while r1 == 0 or r2 == 0 or r1 == r2:
        r1 = rng.randint(-7, 7)
        r2 = rng.randint(-7, 7)

    p = -(r1 + r2)
    qconst = r1 * r2
    eq = sp.Eq(x**2 + p*x + qconst, 0)
    sols = sorted([r1, r2])

    q = rf"Solve: \({sp.latex(eq)}\)."
    s = rf"\(x = {sols[0]},\, {sols[1]}\)."
    return q, s


TEMPLATES: List[QTemplate] = [
    QTemplate("lin-1", "linear equations", "easy", q_linear_solve_int),
    QTemplate("alg-1", "expansion", "easy", q_expand_simplify),
    QTemplate("ind-1", "indices", "easy", q_indices_simplify),
    QTemplate("fac-1", "factorisation", "medium", q_factorise_monic_quadratic),
    QTemplate("quad-1", "quadratics", "medium", q_quadratic_solve_factor),
]


# ---------------------------
# Selection / rendering
# ---------------------------

def pick_questions(
    rng: random.Random,
    topics: List[str],
    counts: Dict[Difficulty, int],
) -> List[Tuple[str, str, str]]:
    """
    Returns list of (question_latex, solution_latex, template_id)
    """
    topics_set = {t.strip().lower() for t in topics if t.strip()}
    pool = [t for t in TEMPLATES if t.topic.lower() in topics_set] if topics_set else list(TEMPLATES)

    chosen: List[Tuple[str, str, str]] = []
    used_signatures = set()

    def signature(q: str) -> str:
        # crude dedupe: strip spaces
        return "".join(q.split())

    for diff, k in counts.items():
        candidates = [t for t in pool if t.difficulty == diff]
        if not candidates and k > 0:
            raise ValueError(f"No templates available for difficulty={diff} given topics={topics}")

        tries = 0
        while k > 0:
            tries += 1
            if tries > 2000:
                raise RuntimeError("Failed to sample unique questions; expand template pool.")

            tmpl = rng.choice(candidates)
            q, s = tmpl.make(rng)
            sig = signature(q)
            if sig in used_signatures:
                continue
            used_signatures.add(sig)
            chosen.append((q, s, tmpl.id))
            k -= 1

    rng.shuffle(chosen)
    return chosen


def load_template(path: str) -> str:
    with open(path, "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
        return f.read()


def main() -> None:
    ap = argparse.ArgumentParser()
    ap.add_argument("--level", required=True)
    ap.add_argument("--title", required=True)
    ap.add_argument("--topics", default="")
    ap.add_argument("--n", type=int, required=True)
    ap.add_argument("--easy", type=int, default=0)
    ap.add_argument("--medium", type=int, default=0)
    ap.add_argument("--hard", type=int, default=0)
    ap.add_argument("--seed", type=int, default=0)
    ap.add_argument("--out", required=True)
    ap.add_argument("--spec", required=True)
    ap.add_argument("--template", default="assets/worksheet_template.tex")
    args = ap.parse_args()

    if args.easy + args.medium + args.hard != args.n:
        raise ValueError("easy+medium+hard must equal n")

    topics = [t.strip() for t in args.topics.split(",") if t.strip()]
    rng = random.Random(args.seed if args.seed != 0 else 123456)

    counts = {"easy": args.easy, "medium": args.medium, "hard": args.hard}
    qs = pick_questions(rng, topics, counts)

    questions_tex = "\n".join([rf"\item {q}" for (q, _s, _id) in qs])
    solutions_tex = "\n".join([rf"\item {s}" for (_q, s, _id) in qs])

    tpl = load_template(args.template)
    rendered = (
        tpl.replace("%%LEVEL%%", args.level)
           .replace("%%TOPICS%%", ", ".join(topics) if topics else "(mixed)")
           .replace("%%DATE%%", str(date.today()))
           .replace("%%SEED%%", str(args.seed))
           .replace("%%TITLE%%", args.title)
           .replace("%%SUBTITLE%%", f"Level: {args.level} \\quad Topics: {', '.join(topics) if topics else 'Mixed'}")
           .replace("%%QUESTIONS%%", questions_tex)
           .replace("%%SOLUTIONS%%", solutions_tex)
    )

    os.makedirs(os.path.dirname(args.out), exist_ok=True)
    with open(args.out, "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
        f.write(rendered)

    spec_obj = {
        "level": args.level,
        "title": args.title,
        "topics": topics,
        "n": args.n,
        "counts": counts,
        "seed": args.seed,
        "template_ids": [tid for (_q, _s, tid) in qs],
    }
    os.makedirs(os.path.dirname(args.spec), exist_ok=True)
    with open(args.spec, "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
        json.dump(spec_obj, f, indent=2)

    print(f"Wrote: {args.out}")
    print(f"Wrote: {args.spec}")


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

This is intentionally small but **extensible**: add more `QTemplate`s to grow your question bank. In practice, you’ll build out templates per syllabus topic.

---

## 6) `references/house_style.md` (what makes it “tutoring-grade”)

This file is not required, but it’s exactly the kind of “institutional knowledge” skills are good at keeping on disk. citeturn4view0turn5view0

```md
# House style (SGMathTuition)

- Language: short, direct, no fluff.
- Questions: exam-style; no cartoons; no “story time” unless asked.
- Answers: concise final forms; minimal working.
- Consistency:
  - Use \( \) for inline math and \[ \] for displayed math.
  - Integers preferred unless specified.
  - Avoid absolute value notation in questions unless the user explicitly allows it.
- Difficulty:
  - Easy: direct application of one skill.
  - Medium: 2-step or requires rearrangement.
  - Hard: integrates 2+ topics or has a trap/case-split (avoid piecewise unless allowed).
```

---

## 7) How you actually use this skill in Codex (app + CLI)

### In the Codex app
- Type `/` to see commands; type **`$` to invoke a skill** (and enabled skills can appear as slash commands). citeturn0search1  
Example prompt:

> `$sgmath-worksheet`  
> Level: Sec 3 A-Math  
> Topics: linear equations, factorisation, quadratics, indices  
> 16 questions; 6 easy, 7 medium, 3 hard  
> Output LaTeX; solutions concise; no absolute value in questions; avoid piecewise

### In the Codex CLI
- Run `/skills` to pick it, or just mention `$sgmath-worksheet` in your prompt. Skills support explicit invocation and can also be implicitly selected based on the `description`. citeturn1search0turn4view0

---

## 8) Multi-agent workflow for tutoring (this is where it gets juicy)
Skills become more powerful when you use **parallel threads**:

- **Thread A:** `$sgmath-worksheet` generate the *easy+medium* portion  
- **Thread B:** `$sgmath-worksheet` generate the *medium+hard* portion (different seed)  
- **Thread C:** “review thread” that checks duplicates, reorders for pedagogy, and enforces house style (still using the same skill so it follows your rules)

Because the skill’s “definition of done” is explicit and its format is consistent, merging outputs becomes mostly mechanical.

---

## 9) Two quick upgrades you’ll probably want next
1) **Add more templates + topic tags** (the generator is only as good as its template library).  
2) **Add verification hooks** (SymPy checks, plug-in tests, or numeric sampling) for templates where errors are easy to introduce.

If you tell me your target level (e.g., Sec 1 algebra vs JC H2 calculus) and your favorite question styles, I can extend the template library in the script so it matches your real worksheets more closely.  

(Also: if you already have a question bank in Markdown/LaTeX/JSON, you can expose it via an MCP server and declare it in `openai.yaml` dependencies so the skill can retrieve from it automatically.) citeturn5view0turn4view0
